heading: Overview
text:
manual live document automatically updated changes made underlying model code documentation.fireSense model implements data-driven wildfire ignition, escape, spread sub-models sensitive climate vegetation feedbacks (Marchal et al. 2017b, ; 2019).
two stages modelling workflow: fitting corresponding statistical models process, subsequently using models prediction.

heading: 1.1.7 Usage
code:
Require(c("SpaDES.core", "SpaDES.tools"))

set.seed(1)

nx <- ny <- 100L
n <- nx * ny
r <- raster(nrows = ny, ncols = nx, xmn = -nx/2, xmx = nx/2,
    ymn = -ny/2, ymx = ny/2)

# Create a map ignition probabilities
ignitionProbRaster <- gaussMap(r, scale = 10, var = 1e-04, speedup = nx/500,
    inMemory = TRUE)

# Create a map of escape probabilities
escapeProbRaster <- gaussMap(r, scale = 50, var = 0.01, speedup = nx/500,
    inMemory = TRUE)

# Create a map of spread probabilities
spreadProbRaster <- gaussMap(r, scale = 300, var = 0.05, speedup = nx/500,
    inMemory = TRUE)

# outputDir <- file.path(tempdir(), 'outputs')
times <- list(start = 1, end = 100, timeunit = "year")

modules <- list("fireSense")

# Pass objects found in the global environment to the
# simList environment
objects <- list(ignitionProbRaster = ignitionProbRaster, escapeProbRaster = escapeProbRaster,
    spreadProbRaster = spreadProbRaster)

# paths <- list( # cachePath = file.path(outputDir,
# 'cache'), modulePath = '..'  # inputPath = inputDir, #
# outputPath = outputDir )

paths <- list(modulePath = "..")

mySim <- simInit(times = times, params = parameters, modules = modules,
    objects = objects, paths = paths)

spades(mySim)

heading: 2.1 Module Overview
text: Prepare data required fireSense_IginitionFit, fireSense_EscapeFit, fireSense_SpreadFit modules.

heading: 2.1.1 Module summary
text:
module uses historical fire, vegetation, climate raster data generate data used fit three processes captured fireSense (Marchal et al. 2017b, ; 2019): fire ignition, fire escape (probability ignition results fire greater cell resolution), fire spread.
landscape data collected two snapshots: 2001 2011, vegetation composition biomass years assumed influenced fires two periods, 2002-2011 2012-2021, respectively.
Unlike vegetation data, climate data assumed seasonal annual, matched year fire occurred.
climate variable(s) must used model fire ignition escape, can vary spread.

heading: 2.1.1.0.1 Fuel classes:
text:
module can optionally estimate fuel classes forested non-forested areas.
non-forested mechanism simpler: combines landcover classes based similar historical propensity burn estimated using GLM, reducing arbitrary amount classes target amount (default, two).
example, bryoids non-treed wetland might combined one class, shrubland grassland another.estimation forested fuel classes complex.
module initially treat species separate fuel class attempt reduce number fuel classes target amount.
uses GLM estimate relationship biomass species, present pixel, likelihood likelihood pixel burning.
species, model fitting data subset removing pixels species present.
Additionally, species priori fuel class.
default fuel classes interpretation FBP classes can viewed via LandR::sppEquivalencies_CA$FuelClass.Individual tree species grouped fuel classes according following logic: first, abundance species assessed, calculated proportion landscape given species represents 10% biomass pixel.
“Rare” species (abundance < 5%) combined another species present fuel class.
two options, grouped order abundance, least .
possible resulting number fuel classes fewer target amount multiple species “rare”.
resulting number unique fuel classes greater target amount, next least abundant species combined.
However, non-rare species combined, must also coefficient sign, non-significant sign.
one species similar fuel class coefficient sign, grouped based abundance, least .
default, module aim five forested fuel classes, two non-forested fuel classes, youngAge (described ), total eight.::: {.example #semi-automated fuel classes}
7 species initially present landscape; 2 must combined achieve target 5
case, Betu_pap Popu_tre combined due low abundance (above10PctRelB)
Pice_gla Pice_eng combined due Abie_las abundant. Pice_mar Pinu_con

heading: 2.1.1.0.2 Special cases: youngAge, missingLCC, and treed wetland
text:
fireSense uses youngAge class distinguish areas recently burned (default within past 15 years), updates landscape snapshots accordingly.
example, conifer pixel burned 2009, subsequent observations pixel converted youngAge, prior observations unchanged.
Additionally, 2011-2011 landscape snapshot adjusted ensure areas correctly classified burned prior 2001 within period relevant youngAge class.
default, forested non-forested classes convert youngAge following fire, however user can disable behaviour latter class via parameter nonForestCanBeYoungAge.related consideration whether treed wetland (land cover class NTEMS land cover product used default) treated variant forested landcover non-forest cover.
decision determines whether biomass tree species treed wetland included covariate fireSense models, non-wetland forest species, whether treed wetland instead considered land cover class, similar shrubland grassland, example.
wetland tree species distinct non-wetland species, decision may less consequence.
object nonForestedLCCGroups takes precedence determining fuel classes; land cover value non-treed wetland included , counted non-forest regardless whether appears parameter forestedLCCclasses.
approach allows treed wetland simulated forest simulation models (.e., LandR) without explicitly treated forest fireSense.
treed wetland absent nonForestedLCCGroups forestedLCCclasses, considered non-flammable land cover, land cover class.fireSense_dataPrepFit estimate fuel classes, also special class termed missingLCC.
class encompasses pixels forested land cover class absent objects cohortData2011 cohortData2001.
frequent reason exclusion forest pixels LandR tree species data pixel.
Therefore, available species biomass, pixels treated non-forest land cover, must assigned one groups nonForestedLCCGroups.Finally, fuel classes modelled biomass instead presence/absence, log biomass used, converting instances zero biomass fuelclass one log minimum observed level (default, 100 $g/m2).

heading: 2.1.3.0.2 prepIgnitionFitData
text:
event prepares ignition data.
pixels individual landscape snapshots 2002-2011 2012-2020 converted voxels aggregating fuel class rasters according parameter P(sim)$igAggFactor calculating mean cover biomass within.
Ignitions summed within voxels every year, data ultimately contain one row voxel year, number ignitions, mean annual climate within voxel, mean amount fuel class (whether biomass cover) additional columns.
probability estimates fitted model can interpreted resolution fitted data, template form aggregated raster output sim$ignitionFitRTM, contains attribute nonNAs, number pixels aggregated raster non-NA data.

heading: 2.1.3.0.3 prepEscapeFitData
text:
rather simple event adds “escapes” column data table prepared prepIgnitionFitData, escape ignition resulted fire greater resolution flammableMap raster (area voxel).
also builds formula object hasn’t supplied, performs minor data quality control (e.g., ensuring fire escapes outnumber ignitions voxel).

heading: 2.1.3.0.4 prepSpreadFitData
text:
data used fit fire spread model differs ignition escape several ways.
First, Fire Spread data includes fires anthropogenic origins, whereas default Ignition dataset includes natural origin.
Second, utilizes spatial subset landscape buffering fire polygons extracting climate landscape data within.
massively reduces spread dataset removing pixels interest model calibration, .e., due lack observed fires.
size buffer dependent upon parameter P(sim)$areaMultiplier.Second, fire must contain corresponding point ignition located inside fire polygon flammable pixel.
object called spreadFirePoints differentiate similar object used Ignition process.
latter different contains fires sizes (.e., smaller resolution sim$rasterToMatch), corresponding polygon object, limited fires natural origin.
spreadFirePoints supplied, default behaviour calculate centroids Fire Spread data select nearest flammable pixel inside fire polygon event centroid satisfy criteria.Lastly, youngAge category calculated year individually.
example, default 2001 pixel estimated 12 years removed last disturbance 2001, pixel fell inside fire buffer 2006, longer youngAge, 12 + (2006-2001) exceed parameter P(sim)$youngeAgeThreshold.
Similar adjustments made pixels initially non-youngAge, burned earlier year, re-appear buffer later fires.
contrast, Ignition Fire data annually resolve `youngAge class.prepareIgnitionFit prepareEscapeFit, model formula object created hasn’t supplied user.
Lastly, reduce object size bare minimum sake lengthy optimization procedure employed spreadFit, data organized annually-varying non-annual components.
former include climate variables youngAge class, organized list data.tables, named year, containing aforementioned covariates, whether pixel burned buffer, fire ID belongs, year fire.
non-annual components sorted list two data.tables, one fire period, names include every year (e.g sim$nonAnnual_SpreadFitCovariates$Year2001_Year2002_Year2003...).

heading: 5.1.1 Module summary
text:
Fit statistical models can used parameterize fire spread component simulation models (e.g., fireSense (Marchal et al. 2017b, ; 2019)).
module implement Pattern Oriented Modelling (POM) approach derive spread probabilities final fire sizes. 
Spread probabilities can vary pixels, thus reflect local heterogeneity environmental conditions.
